title: Are certificates from Udemy, edX, and Coursera of any worth? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have two perspectives to offer here: Perspective #1: Coursera is the reason I got my first job in tech. After college, my first career was in music performance and sound design. While I studied some computer science and psychology, music was my passion. However, at a certain point I realized that the business models in the music industry were completely broken, and reaching success as a performer is basically like winning the lottery—even some of the most talented musicians alive are just scraping by. When I needed to make a career shift, I took a Coursera course in Social Network Analysis (taught by Lada Adamic at the University of Michigan). I attended a conference on Social Network Analysis and ended up in conversation with John Kelly—the CEO of a social data startup (now called Graphika). He suggested we grab coffee, and a few weeks later I was hired. My liberal arts education at Sarah Lawrence College contributed greatly to my skills for the job—a hybrid role that had me in sales, data analysis, and ultimately led me into product management. But it was my fluency with network analysis that really sealed the deal—a skillset that I acquired entirely from taking that Coursera class. I’ve now built a successful career in tech and lead a team at a major nonprofit. Which leads me to… Perspective #2: As a hiring manager, Coursera credentials wouldn’t sway me. I will speak pretty candidly on this point. I don’t give much weight to the credentials or certifications that someone puts on their resume outside of their formal education and work experience. Real-world industry experience is one of the most valuable things to me in bringing someone onto my team. There’s just a different kind of problem-solving that you develop when working on real challenges with the most up-to-date technologies. They don’t really teach that in online courses. Experience with multiple different frameworks is always best. Overspecialization basically only makes sense if you want to be a Salesforce developer (even then—heaven help you whenever Salesforce finally collapses under its own weight). Second to industry experience, a candidate’s formal education gives me a lot of information about them. Did they end up pursuing work in the degree they got? If not, does that degree inform their thinking in ways that might help them in their role? Taking a Coursera course: It depends on the person. Maybe you’re like me and totally obsessed over the idea of interconnecting webs of human interaction. Maybe you were watching TV while you did the course. Maybe you binged it, got a certification, then promptly forgot everything. It gives me some information about who that person is, but I can’t necessarily trust that they’ve become an expert in that field unless it was a multi-year process of acquiring those credentials (like a job or time spent at an accredited university). tl;dr: You should take online courses in order to learn something new and/or gain a skill, not to add a line to your resume.

The worth of these certificates is a judgment call and will depend on the type of employer or the position you are applying for. All certificates from edX, Udemy and Coursera have their own potential and can be well worth it when used in the right context.  The Udemy ‘certificate of completion’ has the least amount of worth with less academic merit as anyone can be a course instructor.[1] Despite this, most online certificates can at least be used to show your activeness in a specific subject or field and to complement your CV. What are the best certificates for employment potential? If you want to have the best possible impact on your potential employer, you are most likely better off with either Coursera or edX. They provide some of the most highly accredited online courses that are available, from top university degrees to specialization certificates. Coursera is the largest with the most courses, student learners and partnering universities. So naturally it’s a good place to start.[2] Coursera tip #1 You can ‘use the method from this Coursera blog post’ for free trial enrollment to the premium courses designed to master specific career skills. Although certificates are never free on Coursera, in my experience they are some of the lowest in cost and the best in worth for employers.  edX tip #1 Also edX provides an impressive collection of accredited courses, and some consider them more selective of partnering universities. You can see ‘their promotion page’ for discounts on certificates.  Most regular courses are provided free, with certificates as paid extra. They also have many high-end online degrees for the best career impact. Should you add your online certificates your CV? There are more reasons to showcase your online courses than not, older employers may tend to dismiss their worth but this is changing.[3] It can help you to stand out and invites conversation in a job interview.You can emphasis relevant skills of what you can actually do for the company, and guide the interview to the right direction.It can exhibit good character, demonstrating that you have a strong willingness to learn and mature intellectually. Are online graduate degrees worth it? Pursuing a graduate education is a profound decision and a big commitment in both time and cost. According to Georgetown University, graduate degree earnings average $80,000 a year, that’s 30% more than a bachelor of arts degree.[4] Graduates pay $24,812 for their degree on average, while online learning platforms such as Coursera and edX are charging a fraction of that cost. This is proving out to be a game-changer for many students for whom online certification is well worth the lower cost. Online courses also provide more freedom with flexible schedules.  Which ever certificate or online course platform you choose to go with, Coursera, edX or Udemy, it is likely worth it. How much, is up to you. Happy studies and best of job opportunities! Footnotes[1] Earn money by creating and teaching online courses on Udemy. Reach millions of students around the world[2] Coursera - Wikipedia[3] 3 Reasons to Add Online Courses to Your CV and How To Do It[4] Is a Graduate Degree Worth It? | Coursera Blog

Actually yes they are. I recently completed Strategic Management and Innovation from Coursera and I can tell you it does open many possibilities. For a country that doesn't require attested certificates/degrees, it amplifies the possibility of getting your desired employment opportunity. But keep in mind that having a certificate is one thing, proving that you have actually benefited from the course is also a necessity. I have had countless of interviews and my certificates are discussions I usually bring up to show that I have experience and completed courses in those specific fields. However (yes there is a but in this answer), you cannot use some certifications as a replacement due to the fact that its not credited for use with universities, unless they agree. But this doesn't mean its a complete waste. Here in the UAE for example, you require attested documents for specific VISA's in most regions. An attested document is a verified document from the issuing country to prove its legitimacy according to the current county you are employed at. This usually affects salaries, travel requirements and professions in my case. Some UAE governments have even partnered up with Coursera making courses compulsory for certain professions and designations. And from interviewing numerous job seekers in the past, those that present certificates from these brands are usually showing initiative that they are eager to learn on their own time. If you do have certificates from these institutes, make sure you actually know what you studied as many employers ask you how this could benefit your performance in their company. I have been asked and asked these questions multiple times, due to the main fact that there are people who rush through the courses and expect this will help them achieve a larger salary or higher position. If you have studied multiple certifications in a specific field, such as Management, over a course of a year or more, there is a possibility in some countries that this can be seen as a higher educational qualification, equivalent to a 1 year college diploma.

I. What are the “Courses and Certificates”.  The “Courses” are available online, when talking in terms of the various types of the websites, and on the completion of the courses, the “Certificates” are provided as the form of the token, or the entity, which ensures, that, the particular user has successfully completed the given set of “Course” respectively. II. Are certificates from the “Udemy, edX, and Coursera of any worth. Yes, definitely. In fact, every piece of content out there has some worth attached to it. Nothing in the universe comes and becomes freely available. There has to be some price, everything comes with the price. The time is passing, the clock is ticking, the age is increasing, day by day, so, even, if the user thinks, whether what is it's worth, so, remember, the user is already paying it's price, directly or indirectly, and, so, the content out there has its own worth. Now, practically speaking, from the job point of view, so, definitely, each and every course has its worth, because, the person who have made that course, has put their heart and soul in creating the content, and if, it is so, so, definitely, it is of importance. Always remember, one rule in life, “The more you learn , the more you earn”. And it is quite true fact. The whole concept behind it is that, suppose talking in terms of the “Software Industry”, so what one normal person who is in that particular field needs. They need a good job with high paying salary, working in the corporate world. Am I right? Yes, of-course! Now, what is the role of the courses available on the internet. “The main aim of the courses available on the internet is to provide the user with the proper knowledge and guidance and skillset, in order to make them, suitable for the particular type of the job, or to provide and learn new and new things”So, their main purpose is to create job oriented people, who are able to work in their field of the interest. And now, it does not matter, on the larger scale, that which courses are to be done, either free or paid, because practically speaking, “The final goal of going through the online course is to learn something new and, in most, cases, to gain the knowledge, which required to crack the interview, in general” respectively. There would be certain courses which could be in high demand, due to their great content as well. But, in general terms, any type of the knowledge, that is gained through the courses, it can be either any course, either paid course, or even the free course, is important, and it is the key factor in deciding, whether the “Candidate is able to crack the interview or not” respectively. So, at last, but not the least, do remember, these things in the life, that, “Knowledge is Power”, and hence, always, the person must be willing to learn and gain, new knowledge, and hence, gain experience, so that, they could improve themselves more and more, in terms of the life respectively. Until, than, STAY ACTIVE, POSITIVE, AND MOTIVATED. Thanks For Reading ✍️

Well, the question is not so easy. Let’s dig a bit deeper into it. Different providers. Udemy - market which offers HUGE amount of courses of different topics. From “sewing” to building an AI. Hard to say are all of them worth. The reason is, those courses provided by anyone who wants to teach. You, my dear reader, may create a course there as well. Now, let’s think about how many of those courses created by professionals (and no - I do not mean people who just has some degree, but those who really understand the topic which they’re going to teach). I have some strange feeling that it won’t be 100% of the whole amount of courses. IF the course was created by a professional, could creator make a mistake? It might be the case. But regardless there are really good courses over there (I know it - I saw it). Answering the question - well for the money you pay (not to much for registered users) you will get benefit in case if the course is good. + Shows desire for self-development, knowledge - No worth for employer, “not verifiable” ( “well it is and it even has a number”(crowd shouting) - yes, but I guess employer won’t be interesting in verification from “Bin&Gin co” for “Any programming language rubbish to super-hacker-mega-coder, ready for action guy 35 hours on demand video” certificate). edX - provider who has verifiable certificates from different institutions and organizations. Also has a big variety of topics but not so big as in previous provider, due to not any mortal can create a course in there. From one point of view - it is good. In my opinion you can trust it more (BUT always double-check!!!). In addition you don’t have to buy the course straight away. You can try it for free first and then decide to pay or not. Why its like that - well, because here you pay to get a “paper”. You are free to get the knowledge for free, but if you want a verified certificate from some institution (check the list on the site), you’ll have to pay, which is, I think, fair enough. + Verified certs, pay only to get them - Less courses To underline everything what was told. I am a user of both Udemy and edX (didn’t use Coursera, so won’t give any info on it). Both platforms has their advantages and disadvantages (ok “less courses” on edX is not so bad, but maybe you’ll find some - yourself). In relation of the knowledge - both platforms may offer good content. In relation of the certification… well I would say edX is better to choose (from the value for employer point of view). But choose your destiny and try it yourself. Have a nice day ;)

As for me, I searched for this question a lot, I don't have my own academic experience to give you an accurate answer. But I actually found a cliché throughout the internet, and I'd like to summarize it; mixing it with my own point of view :D Certificates prove that you're a life-long learner.Certificates show that you have the guts and the determination to start a project yourself triggered by your own motivation.Obviously, these certificates will enrich your CV (let's suppose they didn't, they wouldn't do any harm anyway).Since the courses are verified and offered by prestigious universities, they have already gained an academic value.Finally, wherever there's money, there's value (I guess nobody puts that this way :p).Either way monsieur, I recommend you to go for it, cause it's a good time investment. And don't worry about the 50$ -just consider you spared them by being stingy on a date, or you bought a simple polo shirt instead of a fancy Armani one (just imagining) :D

If I am reading a CV which mentions MOOC certificates for complementary / secondary skills, I would get the impression that the person takes an active interest in their personal development. This is a very positive sign. The certification isn't the key part here; I am interested that they are undertaking independent learning in new skills, and so just saying “I have completed online courses in xyz…” would be just as good. I guess certificates would score a couple of bonus points as it shows a level of commitment and investment, though it wouldn't factor significantly in my decision. However, certificates in a core skill could make me question their experience. Say, for example, they claim to have X years experience in Python, and list a recent certificate for an online Python course. I would question why they took that training, as these courses generally cover the very basic fundamentals. I would also question whether they have any real world experience. This is not necessarily an instant cause to reject them, but it is a potential red flag. So, in summary: Online training in subjects which complement your core competencies are good.Paid certificates are not worth much; more important is a demonstration of continuing personal development.Certificates in a core skill required of the role don't count for anything.

Believe it or not, the global e-learning market is growing significantly. Surveys predict that it is expected to reach $238 billion by 2024, with a growth rate of 8.5%. Not only individuals, but the corporate sector is also embracing e-learning. This proves that e-learning has a great scope in the future and training providers like Udemy, EdX, and Coursera would continue to be popular among learners. Now coming to the certifications from these organizations, any course certificate is valuable only when you are able to prove the skills you gained from them. Udemy, for instance, has loads of courses regarding every subject. But, many are not worth taking and you need to research thoroughly to get the most relevant course. If money isn’t a concern, you can go for EdX, Coursera, or Simplilearn. Many renowned universities collaborate with them and you get the benefit of learning from highly experienced trainers. Now if you are expecting to get a job by highlighting these certifications, make sure that you have some experience in the related field. For freshers, it may be difficult to crack any job interview based on these certifications. But if you already have the experience, these certifications are really worthy in helping you stand out of the crowd and paving your way for your dream job.

If you are just paying for the certificate I would say definitely not worth the price. Prospective employers and anyone else will believe you when you say you have done the course and you can show a screenshot of the congratulations page when you finish the course if you need proof. I do think that in some cases paying for the certificate is worth it and that is because it also unlocks more features in the course. Some skills are hard to learn. When you pay for a certificate you also get access to more of the exams and you will have your assignments graded. This feedback is often invaluable to see if you are making progress or just following the videos. Another good way to decide if you want to invest the money is to think of how much your time is worth. Think of the money as an investment against your time, it will help you stay motivated through the harder parts of the learning curve. If the course is 48 hours over 12 weeks then $75 might be a good ideaIf you just want a quickie to gain a quick skill then take the free optionHopefully, that helps we have a break down of online certificates if you are interested. One of the great things about learning online is that it is low commitment buying one certificate is not the same as taking a degree you can change your mind and start again pretty easily. If you aren’t sure about the certificate start with the free option then upgrade if you love the course or want some more feedback. Good luck with whichever route you choose!

I’ve used EDX and Udemy, the latter quite extensively, and I’m about to go for some courses with Coursera too. I did not get a degree (so far), I just worked a lot in several jobs until I got fired. I do not have any money for Uni and it is not always easy to learn on the job. So I discovered Udemy and I am learning a lot! Thing is it is a bit of researching to be done, buying and try the courses out. Most of them are not worth a penny but some of them are amazing and some good. The great thing is that people on it, at least the one with good courses, give you what they learned and used throughout their experience, it is like sitting down with a colleague and learn. I’m grateful to Udemy because learning is affordable. As per EDX, I loved it but also in there, just because courses are from university does not mean they’ll be able to give you what you need. It depends. And as to if they are worth to get you a job..well…I have not found a job yet…already 7 months now…but I keep trying and keep learning..So good luck with your life ;)

I think that any form of learning, including simply studying YouTube subjects, is worthwhile. Whether an employer will see it that way, I don’t know. But the employer, IMO, should see the effort put in. A larger question is whether a traditional college or university degree is worthwhile. I’ve seen some indication (on YouTube) that perhaps not, at least not as much as one would wish. Any kind of training or studies in a particular, marketable field should be worthwhile. Then, there is the situation in the real world where some might look at their managers or supervisors and wonder where they got their management degrees. Of course, they don’t likely have one…and it shows. Following-up: IMO any kind of college/university degree is likely to make one a more “polished” person, which will usually show.

Question: Are certificates from Udemy, edX, and Coursera of any worth?  Let us see. These certificates will only add value if you are willing to put the required time and effort to pursue the knowledge and skills that these certificates showcase. If you just want these certificates to make your C.V look more presentable, then these certificates will backfire on you. For example here are a couple of scenarios. Person A has an exceptional understanding of Machine Learning (let us say), but doesn’t have a certificate to prove it, but he shows his knowledge by calmly answering all the required questions on his interview. Now would he still need a certificate? I guess not. Since person B has a certificate for Machine Learning, this will make the interviewer think that maybe Machine Learning is his strong suit. If he can answer all the questions with ease, then yes, his certificate will help. Otherwise… bye-bye. So, in short… “Certificates will only add worth if you know how to defend them. Either they will boost your credentials or they will be your worst nightmare.”  Hope this helps.

If you’re looking for a new job they might have some value as others have pointed out. Most recruiters and HR staff just search for keywords and certificates are those keywords. I mean, you’re paying for keywords in your CV or LinkedIn profile. Following that, they’ll have no value, they can even backfire to you because the next interviews will test your knowledge. For instance, for my current job, I had to pass 2 interviews with HR and then another 2 technical interviews plus a sample project that I had to deliver. The technical interviewers didn’t care at all about my academic degrees. However, I think that paid certificates are useful. It motivates you to study because you have paid for it and the quality of the course it’s usually much higher than for free courses. Furthermore, learning by experience it’s very important but you also need to learn the formalities that you learn from an official/professional course. These formalities include technical vocabulary, uncommon features (e.g. rare Unix commands), or reasoning behind some common practices. You usually don’t learn these “on the street”.

Edx and Coursera offer MOOC (Massive Open Online Course) i.e., Courses from prestigious universities in the world like Harvard, Yale, Stanford, Imperial College London etc. Certificate of a particular course is offered either by Coursera or EDX and is endorsed by respective University. In some cases you can also transfer Credit of a course. On the other hand Udemy also offers certificate after completion of a course. First thing about Udemy is that the courses on the platform are not created by Udemy they are created by third party creators. Anybody can create a course there, including you and me. Now some courses are from experts while other are created by inexperienced people unlike Coursera and Edx. At the end of the course Udemy will provide you certificate anyway regardless of the quality of the course. I would also like to mention one thing here that , I don't say that all the courses on Udemy are below the mark. There are thousands of high-quality courses there. So, in conclusion Edx and Coursera have no comparison with Udemy.

Yes, definitely! Courses from Udemy, edX and Coursera are of great worth. When you mention on your CV or resume that you have completed certain courses from these websites, it goes to show a lot about you as a person- You are a motivated and hardworking person who does not like to sit idle.You have a keen interest in learning and expanding your knowledge.You are a dynamic person who wants to grow and enhance his/her skills in a particular field of interest.You wish to learn more than what is simply given in a textbook.Your potential employer will be immediately impressed by your keenness to learn more and grow. It is a good idea to opt for those courses which will provide you a certificate, even if they are charging some minimal amount for it. Hence, don’t have second thoughts about enrolling for an online course and use it on your CV. Check out Quantel, an unparalled platform for college students, interns and entrepreneurs to connect and assist each other. On Instagram-quantel.in, message for any related queries.

How do you define “worth”, my friend? If you want to use a single certificate as a proxy for a university degree, then they'll hardly be worth it since a 4-week marketing course can't rival a 4-year graduate program. BUT if you take several of those, engage in their communities, read their references and so on and so forth, you'll understand things better than many graduates out there and probably will be applying everything soon, meaning your experience will certify your papers instead of the other way around. It happened to me: I'm in my third self-made career and owe it all to edX and Coursera. Today I work in a multinational and many specialists there have lower expertise than I do. (Not saying I'm better than them; their experience probably brought them skills that would make a joke out of me.)

Not for me. This is an example of an old tradition that has definitely changed. As an employer myself, I receive many CVs and resumes with thousands of certificates, but when it comes to a test or challenge, things look a lot different. Notwithstanding I am a lawyer by profession, I learned to program by using many of these new ways of learning, being the certificate the least important thing I cared about. In my case, I was looking to learn a new topic to achieve a greater objective: create a company. My first online course, for example, helped me create an App. If my goal was to look for a job, I would rather show THAT (App) to my future employer rather than a certificate. A paper, digital or not, will never replace the value a course gave you to achieve a greater goal or objective.

If you fail to solve business problem with your line of certificates then they all are useless piece of crap and will make you even worst in front of those who you are approaching to work for - what matter is your ability to solve problems, analyze the situation, bring up solutions, no give up attitude in complicated issue and helping business / company grow with your skills and expertise - if YOU are worthy then YOU will remain IN the game otherwise you’ll be given a BYE BYE along with all your certificates :) It doesn’t matter how many certificates do you have - bring your skills with confidence in the game to come up with real solutions and solve out problems.

Don't know about edX and Coursera but Udemy Certificate doesn't have any worth. Before you spam the comments, let me tell you why You can get a Udemy Certificate by just paying the course fee, then click on mark as watched/read with in 15–30 min you will get your certificate. thats why it have no worth it. Udemy have tons of good Courses but they don't have standards for certificate distribution, they should atleast take some test. Mostly any Certificate is valuable, which require some work from the student. like Nptel Certificate, Oracle Certificate etc. It may be helpful for you to build up your CV/Resume but In the end Udemy Certificate is useless. I am not pessimist just showing you the truth. Thank you, ( ╹▽╹ )

Short answer: Don’t do courses for the certificate, do it for yourself. I’m frequently hiring people and looking at a lot of CVs. When I find the section of Certificates, the way I see it is “Things that you have an interest in”. I can’t say you have knowledge of something just because you have a certificate, especially those that you can complete in a matter of week(s). At most, you can say that you scratched the surface and have a superficial knowledge. Learning involves study AND practicing, and the more you do it, the better you get. These courses give you little practice and when they do, you are in a controlled environment, with hints and the problem well defined. That is not the real world. The lack of experience when you have simply studied something is an important matter when hiring someone. I’m not criticizing these courses, in fact, I myself have taken a lot of them and I’m always learning something new (I like Coursera a lot), but I know the limitation they provide for learning. Practice! I didn’t put the courses I’ve taken in my CV, but the ones I did, was for curiosity, personal interest or just to remember some subjects I learned long ago. Here are some of them, in which I concluded: Social PsychologyMoralities of Everyday LifeDeveloping your musicianshipFinancial MarketsAs you can see, subjects of my own interest.

It depends from person to person. Before enrolling to a course please do check the content, rating and the scope of the subject, because many courses are paid so you must be particular to choose your course. For the one who actually needs to improve their skills these courses are worth, & if they are confident on that topic, surely they can add the certificate in their cv.For college students, they can submit these certificates in order to get activity points from their university.There are some people who will get coupon codes to specific paid courses, if they don't utilize it effectively (in the sense that if they skip the lectures) it might gonna be a bad impact for them in future.LinkedIn- you can add the certificates in LinkedIn certifications.For the people who are in search of job interviews, they can have these certificates if the authority agrees.

Any sort of learning initiative is always welcome. A certificate on the CV signals that commitment to life long learning However, being a Udemy Instructor myself on a host of topics like Financial Modeling, Advanced MS Excel, Job Finance and Finance for Non Finance, I find that students are besotted more by the certification than the learning - this is a dangerous trend Knowledge will anyday rule supreme in the job interviews and not these certificates ( we all know that in some cases, it's just a matter of spending a 50$ - they are given to all and sundry and not just say a % of students enrolled - wouldn't a prospective employer be able to see through that ) For instance , even if you havent paid for the certificate , if you can prepare a financial model after undergoing an e-learning course, I would rate you higher than someone who has the certificate but starts fumbling the moment s/he is asked a couple of piercing questions

I have taken courses on udemy and edx ,they have their worth in terms of knowledge but for a professional career it just filling your resume which might taken in consideration during your interview,but no one offer you a job by just looking at your certificates of all the mentioned sites,Also,  It clearly mentioned on udemy page regarding it’s certification, Whereas edx and coursea certificates can be used for formal accreditation However you can use all these certificates at your LinkedIn resume. But I will recommend you to take course on udacity , it has professional as well as worth in terms of knowledge,and companies (like infosys, wipro,etc) take it’s certificate into consideration too. But at the end KNOWLEDGE is all that matters.

if a young man with a Bachelor of Science in Computer science from his country, moves to a more tech competitive country and he is not good enough to get a job in that field. Luck and get a job as an assistant accountant. Now he learns on the job and also get the experience. Earning a certificates from edx in one of the accounting courses can boost his CV, and also give him the right attitude to apply for a higher paying job as an accountant. So it depends on the situation you find yourself and there are different easy ways to earn a certificate from one of this online training platform. If at the end, you do not have the required knowledge or experience on Job, there is a very high chance that your certification may become wasteful.

some questions you need to focus on here are How, Why and When when are you pursuing these certificates? Have you been away from work for some time and you want to catch up with the business world? why are you pursuing these certificates? Is there a gap in your cv that you want to fill, perhaps you are aware of other colleagues with a similar cv to yours and feel the need to be more competitive? how are you going to pursue these certificates? Are you willing to study hard to find yourself in a place where you can apply for them? maybe you re just having fun. In this case my opinion is you don't need to pay for them. All other cases , yes you should :-)

No Certificates + Sound Knowledge about subject = A good job Certificates + Sound Knowledge about subject = Still a good job Certificates + Not proper knowledge = No job So, certificates are just little plus points for you. They cannot give you success unless you have proper knowledge about the subjects. But yes, the highly rated and difficult to attain certificates like AWS Certification and Google Cloud Certifications are really valuable thorugh your career.

I have taken courses on udemy and edx ,they have their worth in terms of knowledge but for a professional career it just filling your resume which might taken in consideration during your interview,but no one offer you a job by just looking at your certificates of all the mentioned sites,Also,  It clearly mentioned on udemy page regarding it’s certification, Whereas edx and coursea certificates can be used for formal accreditation nonetheless you can use all these certificates at your LinkedIn application. But I shall suggest you to take program on udacity , this has expert also really worth with regards to understanding,and companies (like infosys, wipro,etc) go on it’s certificate under consideration too. But at the conclusion KNOWLEDGE is all that really matters.

I have taken courses on udemy and edx ,they have their worth in terms of knowledge but for a professional career it just filling your resume which might taken in consideration during your interview,but no one offer you a job by just looking at your certificates of all the mentioned sites,Also,  It clearly mentioned on udemy page regarding it’s certification, Whereas edx and coursea certificates can be used for formal accreditation nevertheless you can use these certificates at your LinkedIn application. But I shall recommend you to definitely simply take program on udacity , it offers expert including well worth with regards to understanding,and companies (like infosys, wipro,etc) go on it’s certificate into consideration too. But by the end KNOWLEDGE is perhaps all that really matters.

The knowledge and the skill that you develop from these courses is the worth that you get. For ex: Computer Science is one such domain where what matters more is your skill set and not the degree paper that you carry in your hand. The key to excel in this course is to choose what to learn ,wisely.You always need to stay updated and keep yourself well acquainted with what’s happening around you. So, these courses from Udemy, edX,Coursera can be a valuable advantage to your side, if you make the right use of it. It might not happen in a single day but it will ,somewhere down the future ,be a great boon to your career.

Formal Education makes you eligible applicants for certain jobs based on their criteria. It is like a gate pass to some more job opportunities. But focus on skills. Formal Education ‘might not’ focus on skills. To fill that gap you need to self educate yourself. One of the easiest and affordable ways you can self educate is by doing courses online. Also, you get a certificate from them as acknowledgment. Formal Education and certificate courses both add to your profile. Cracking the interview is based on your profile (skills), presentation, communication, and persuasion skills. Formal Education alone will not help you as there are so many people with the same Educational background and you will have to stand out from them. Doing additional courses might show that you are a person who is aspiring to learn more, but today all are aware of these websites and everyone attempts to do additional courses. But what is more important is how well can you execute those skills at your workplace. It is not the ‘certificate’ that you should be focused on, rather on ‘skills’ and its ‘execution’.

They are great for your fist job/internship. Every single interview I had loved the fact I had a degree, but also took the time to get some technical skills relevant to what I wanted to do as a career. You have to remember you are not the only person that wants that job, so think of ways that could make you stand out. I highly suggest learning Python and SQL because it will open so many doors for you. Many enterprises now whether it be marketing or business really like candidates with a background in SQL. This is all advice so please do your own research, and best of luck.

Being a community coordinator, I have to screen a lot of profiles everyday. I would say certificates can bring huge add-on values to your profile, especially in the field of design and technology development: Digital design as well as technology softwares keep changing everyday. Online learning definitely prove that you’re equipped yourself with the most updated tools and softwares.Many designers and developers come from different background. Like myself, my first degree was in International Business. But my online credentials in UX design and Front-end dev help me a lot in switching into a new field.Most of the time, I screen for LinkedIn profile, related education (including online certificates) and participated projects when approving an application. Just my personal experience, hope it helps.

I feel instead of doing online courses, first look for the JOB REQUIREMENT and then choose a course to do. for example, if a company is hiring people who are good in python, then apply for the opening and then do online course in Python. If the job requirement is in python, then first mention it on your CV/RESUME and then do online course and certification so that the online course will really help you to fetch the job. And if you asking for gaining knowledge , then yes , because “knowledge has no end”. Hope this helps

I think learning always pays off. So, in this respect I see no harm with these providers. However, they are platforms. They are the means to deliver the content. On this point I want to stress though who provides the certificate? MIT (=content) or Coursera (=platform)? A certificate carries always thebmerit of compektion which in itaelf can be valuable. Add to this that the certificate would be provided by a well known university then this is on par with any other certificate. Most universities today offer their courses also online. Worth whike checking them directly?

Udemy certificates don't hold much value unless u prove you learnt something. For coursera and edx it depends on employers if they want to simply trust them or not as they may or may not be aware about the depth of your course and it's not possible to know about every course. But if u are doing some famous course for example - coursera Andrew NG- deeplearning spécialisation, if you have done they believe you'll be good with deeplearning as many people do this for deep Learning and they are aware of the depth.

Personal testimony. I have learnt all my ICT and teaching skills via coursers.. I usually pick the courses depending on the type of skill I want to get. I used my coursers certificate to obtain accreditation as an examiner and lecturer. I am allowed to do ICT jobs because of the skill and certificates that I have been able to submit to different places seeking my service. I have never tried Udemy or Edx but Coursera certificates are good enough.

I think this is the problem of all Why people focus only on increase the number in certificate rather than improving knowledge. If you have knowledge and no certificate, definitely certificate is just a piece of paper and no one can stop you from doing anything. So, first thing focus on knowledge not on certificate Certificate value only when you have knowledge about this And last coursera is better than other.

I don't feel the certificates are necessary. Up till now I have worked for almost 10 different employers and only two of them asked me copies of my Bachelor/Master degree diplomas. No one ever asked me to provide certificates for the copies completed. If you enrolled at free course and need some form of proof of completing the course, you can make a screenshot of the completes assignments/grades, this is basically the same as a certificate.

Yes and No. Largely No - if you are using it as a passport for jobs etc and focus on completion of courses. Big Yes - if you are looking for the course with maximum ratings/ hours and genuinely interested in learning the relevant pieces (Not all parts of course may be relevant so i generally skip a few non essential segments) Note: This is purely based on usage of Udemy. I have not used other platforms much to be able to comment.

I can answer this answer very well , I am an engineering student and have done courses from Coursera, Udemy, and NPTEL. Let's understand their differences and similarities:- If you are a College student then having certificates from Coursera, Udemy or any other website other than NPTEL won't increase your credits in the semester because these all are non credit courses. While courses on NPTEL will give you credit points for the semester.If you are in school then neither of them going to increase your marks or percentage.If you want to gain knowledge then all these websites are great specifically Coursera.Getting certificates will boost your confidence and the employer's confidence in you.It makes your profile look more presentable and also can add to your LinkedIn.Coursera and NPTEL certificates have one advantage over Udemy and other websites that these are recognised by the universities and if you have to show your certifcation courses, you can use them.Thanks for reading, I hope it helps Do upvote if you found it useful 🙂

For me, they were all useless in terms of advancing a career. All recruiters I went to and showed my CV with those certificates didn’t even bother with them, even though they were relevant. They just made my CV look nicer and bloated but did not in anyway help me in a job search or career advancement. Good for hobby learning on your own time.

There are a couple of different ways one might interpret this question, but if you are specifically inquiring about prestige, as I suppose you might be, let me tell you this. While not every institution or job prospect would recognize these certificates directly at face value, obtaining these certificates by holistically completing the associated courses is valuable in the long run, as you will obtain the skills necessary for many of the jobs you might apply to. Moreover, you might learn something you have never learned before, improving your work ethic as well as overall experience.

Any source of knowledge is worthy investing in. However, some certificates are better than others. Having a certificate is a proof that you know what is happening in that field, it is better than having nothing to show. The most important thing in that certificate is the skills you have gained and you can be able to apply it.

Having finished several courses from edX and Coursera , I feel that I can write the answer very well. When you complete a course you not only get the certificate to show off but also a decent amount of knowledge of that field. Let's take a situation where two people apply for a job having similar experiences , marks and degree. The company will see you based on your CV and you need to stand out. You need to be extraordinary for your dream job. We are living in an age where securing a decent job is so challenging. Therefore , excellent CV, with quality knowledge will always help. It will boost your CV and help your employers to choose the best. They will analyze and respect your interest and voluntary desire for educating yourself.

my names fatih selçuk l am 52 years old ,my job is a english teacher l would like to improve myselves l am still hungury to learn .when l learn something that is makes me fell better beacuse if l have a good knowledge and backround l can give to my student better way about their life and they can sant up on their feet strogly thank you very much

Not at all,,, Literally speaking these certificates are useless until you have the skills or talent,, I too have plethora of certificates with me,,but these certificates are worthless until or unless you have that particular skill for which you enrolled in that particular course …

As someone who has taken several data science courses from different platforms such as DataCamp, EdX, and Coursera, I shared my thoughts about whether it is worth it or not to purchase a verified certificate in this article: Should I Pursue a Verified Certificate for a Massive Open Online Course (MOOC)?  Verified certificate logo, from edx (https://www.edx.org/)

Certificates are useful any way. But the thing is that you learnt something through these courses. If you are not sure that the certificate is useful. Do a project on the things that you learnt, and showcase the project as your expertise. It is not for certificate that you do the courses, it is for knowledge. Remember Coursera or Udemy they offer many courses that are the best, not all. Please do research on the course before you select any.

It totally depend on what your intent is.If you are doing it for the sake of getting certificate and you gain nothing valuable than please don’t do it.Bcoz companies will know that whether you had related skills according to your certificate.Considering that you are a CS guy then you must take up some project after completing your course so that you can prove your skills to company.

Hello, Now there has been increase in awareness & acceptance of these Education platform. But it depends on What exact course you have doneThe Level of knowledge that you got out of it, ( else its of no use)
The Certificates do not matter what matters are the skills you acquire after the study period UDACITY IS THE BEST

The true value of these certificates is the knowledge you get out of them. They may also help marginally when applying for a position if the job directly requires that knowledge, but typically employers will want to see classes completed from formal accredited institutes of higher education.
Certificate from edx and Coursera have value when u include it in your C. V., but certificates from udemy don't have value in point of view of C. V. Since it is not a accredited institute

They do. You may link them in CV. Many companies even reimburse them. The more interesting part is you get global leaders in the profession, and you can ask whichever question you feel. There is just no peer pressure. But there are many courses, please choose courses as per your need and ability. Even you may learn about practicing hobbies, there are so many things to learn!
